title: Euro Coin calibration
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The main goal is to provide a calibration for what ever euro coin you have in your pocket.

This is a pretty basic calibration piece, howsoever it is more powerfull then it seems.
By uncommenting one of the avaliable coins on the bottom of this code you can generate a calibration piece which should have the exact measures (height and diameter) for the Euro piece you have avaliable. There's not much to do, simply uncomment your favorite calibration coin, export the stl (Design -> export STL), slice it, print it, put your coin in the center and calibrate.
For reference: the measures were taken from this [0] German Wikipedia article [0]https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurom%FCnzen#Beschreibung

comments.text: I print 1€ coin but i can fit only 20cent and i check marlin and it's ok
comments.author: CapuTech_96

comments.text: I know this is not the correct place to ask this but my print of the one euro pieve is soo large even a 2euro piece is too small.. I think my marlin configuration is correct, as i measured everything thrice ;-) ! i have a home-build prusa i3 but i cannot seem to find what is causing this 'oversized' prints..  (i'm using slic3r + printrun/prontrface)
comments.author: selsiusx

comments.text: Thank you for this simple piece! What is the outside diameter of the 1 Euro holder. Your page says 38.10mm but when I measure the STL file I get 28.3mm and my part is around 28mm. What is correct?
comments.author: prittstift

comments.text:
Hey,
I'm not sure what page you are refering to.
If you look into the scad-file you'll see that the coin has a diameter of 23.25 and a heigh of 2.38mm
The resulting square is the diameter + 5mm, therefore the edgelength is 23.25 + 5 -> 28.25mm

author: momorientes

title: 3D Scanner based off FabScan open source project (CEBSCAN)

description.text:
This scanner uses Open-source FabScan software as it's base Starting point. It is a work in progress as far as scanning code goes but I'm putting it up here since the 3D printing parts are complete.
Their Site http://hci.rwth-aachen.de/fabscan
I have added a few significantly extend the FabScan model most obviously is the Z dimension using a Ramps 1.4 controller to manage both the plate step as well as the as the height step. If you want to use the second N17 stepper to control height throughout the scan let me know and I can send you the firmware.
The bars and threaded rods are all 5/8 and the steppers are N17's . I used Standard 5MW lasers that you can find all day long from China for 5$ and the digital camera is a Logitech C920 which is about 40 bucks on eBay. The related blog site is www.c2scan.com where you can go for other info and locations for source code.

Light Pin --> D9
Turn Table Motor --> X connector for Motor control
Laser Vertical Motor --> Y connector for Motor Control
Stepper 3 Motor --> Z connector for Motor Control (as modified by me in the post below)
Light Switch --> X Endstop connector
MS Pin --> T0 connector
Please let me know if I am good so I can connect it up to the Ramps 1.4
v/r
Charles

comments.text:
The quick answer is two lasers makes it twice as fast to scan which can be time consuming. The Firmware INO
file is included and the link to the version with scanning for two lasers is below, it looks like just another copy of the scanning code
from the base site but if you look at the notes on some of the files under “Qttest” you will see the reference to Dual laser support. Also although I added Z Axis support for the firmware I have not added that functionality to the scanning code itself yet. This is a big project so I encourage anyone that wants to lend a hand.

Your Photobooth scans

The other day I saw a can colander (like this: http://www.amazon.com/Progressive-International-GT-3966-Can-Colander/dp/B00004S7VI/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1344822907) in the canned vegetable section in the grocery store. My first thought was, "Huh, that could be handy," immediately followed by, "I could print that." So, here it is. This one (the 66mm file) is designed for a specialty food can, but the scad file is parametric, so you can adjust for the size of any. If you have a request for specific sizes, I'd be happy to generate those and post them, just make sure to include the inner diameter of the can you want it to fit (I'll also add 1mm or so for a loose fit). Suggestions welcome. Unlike the commercial version linked above, this one is designed to fit into the can, allowing you to press the contents of the can using the colander if you wish. This thing is a part of a collection of things featured in this post: http://www.protoparadigm.com/blog/2012/08/what-to-do-with-a-3d-printer-make-canning-jar-accessories/

You shouldn't need support material for the lip, but if you do it should only be on the outside and should be quite easy to peel away.
Make sure to use a food-safe plastic.

author: jpan

title: Sporkle Axe (or Sporkle Axapult)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ladies and gentlemen, I proudly present to you the culmination of everything I know, and all I have ever learned, poured into this: the defining 3D model of my life. Whether you're fending off orcs at Minas Tirith or you're just lazy and need to be able to shave while eating your Cheerios, this is the only eating utensil you will ever need -- half spoon, half fork, and half menacing battle axe. Eat efficiently! Defend yourself barbarically! Shave while eating! Behead your fruit! Stop for lunch while chopping wood! You can also get it at Shapeways in a variety of materials, including stainless steel. I recommend solid silver, of course, because it's expensive. I might actually try it in steel and see how it holds an edge. http://www.shapeways.com/model/664341/ UPDATE: Unlock a HIDDEN feature! Hold the axe head in your hand, place a chunk of food on the spork, pull back to flex the shaft, and then release. This works best if the food is set aflame just before launch. Other Sporks of Fury:
Sporkchucks (Sporkchaku): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28485
Chinese Throwing Spork (hire-shuriken): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28638

1) Print.
2) Impale. 
3) Devour.
(I printed at 0.2mm layer height with support material in slic3r.)

author: ncmasone

description.text: Fluorescent Tube Holder - Designed to hold the UV tubes in my PCB exposure box. The ABS has enough spring in it to clip onto the tube. A bit scary at first but it works well. Printed on an UP! Plus using 0.25mm layer thickness and loose fill.

• Print flat side down.
  • Insert M4 nut into holes.
  • Mount to surface using M4x12mm Machine Screws

comments.text: I'm curious why you don't just hold it with the tube sockets? While this might be OK for an exposure box, tubes can get pretty warm if they're ON for awhile. Just something to be aware of.
comments.author: PropellerScience

comments.text: These tubes don't get overly hot being only 15W so its not too bad, but yes it could be a concern. The way I have designed the box didn't allow for the traditional tube holders. I am using screw terminal type connectors on the ends.
comments.author: PropellerScience

comments.text: Really nice design! But would also agree with the previous poster. I'm about to build a UV exposure box myself and I will just use the tube sockets. Allthough, these would be nice to use for somewhere else and in like.. well.. "techno"-style designs, where you just connect wires to the end of the tubes. I don't know, but I can see the use for these! :)
comments.author: Tim_C

author: CHANDAN2302

title: MG Midget winshield washer pump bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an adapter bracket to mount a TAAP universal washer pump ($10 part from local auto parts store vs triple cost specialty part shipped in) in a 1975 MG Midget. The adapter moves the pump up and away from the firewall to make clearance for the downward facing hose barb, and allows for the slightly wider screw spacing. I expect it will work with other MG models and years that use electric washer pumps.
Modeled in Lightwave 3D.

comments.text: +1 because I have a Midget as well :)

title: Arduino Rocket Launcher for 3D Printed Rockets

description.text:
When I was a kid, I loved playing with Estes Rockets, so I decided to get back into the hobby but using all of my maker skizzls. So here's a really cool Arduino Rocket Launcher launching 3D Printed rockets from my MakerBot Replicator2! Enjoy! Fully Open Source for anyone to make! Full Assembly and Launch Instructions are on Instructables! VIDEOS - More Coming Weather Permitting!

Rocket Launch in Slow-Mo Rockets that Work Well

no supports, raft, .200mm thickness. Have fun and be careful!

title: Water Dispenser Lever for Frigidaire Fridge

description.text: This water dispenser lever is for some models of Frigidaire side by side door refridgerators. This lever is designed to be glued onto what usually remains after the original part breaks.

This design might fit some models of side by side door Frigidaire refridgerators with broken water levers. It may or may not be the right fit for your fridge - so make some measurements of this print and your fridge's water lever before you attempt this repair. This replacement part is designed to glue onto the old remaining lever that remains after it fails. You may have to take apart the water and ice dispenser area of your refridgerator to gain access to the lever assembly. See this YouTube video that shows how to do this repair using a standard brand new replacement part: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WBBva8A-VLE. This video will help you repair your fridge whether you are using brand new factory part or glueing on your 3D printed repair part. Be sure to disconnect your fridge from electrical power before working in this part of your fridge. Removing the dispenser assembly screws may run into a few snags if their is corrosion in this area. You may have to cut the heads off a screw or two and back the screws out with vice grips if the heads are too coroded to accept a screw driver. The old broken/failed lever may need to be sanded or trimmed a bit in order to allow the new lever to slip over it. Once you have placed the new lever over the broken lever, glue the new lever onto the broken part using five minute epoxy. Fill in gaps with a two part plumber's putty or steel epoxy. Using an epoxy putty is also a way to reinforce the water lever and new part. Plugging the circuit boards (related to the light and ice panel) back in may be a bit tricky, but is doable. Also note, if you remove the water hose from the panel, you may have to splice in some new hose to make the hose long enough to snake it through the dispenser panel when re-assembling. Check out the following website for general information on repairs to this part of the fridge (which also has info on ordering replacement parts and installing them). http://www.fixya.com/support/t261969-water_dispenser_lever_frigidaire

comments.text:
Hello,
My water dispenser lever broke near the very top where the support at the top that has the swivel bars, meets the large square flapper. Not sure how this would work with that? Maybe this is designed for use where the flapper breaks a bit further down?

comments.text: If only I'd been printing when mine broke the first time! Well, there's always the second time.

The plastic stake included with the typical landscape light is easily broken. They aren't available in stores, so I made one to fit my brand of light. It includes the threaded portion that engages the light. The thread is M20 x 1.5. Works great!

description.text: Created with JavaCSG: https://github.com/miho/JavaCSG and https://github.com/miho/JavaFXScad
Pinned laser cut box.

Laser cut from 3mm plywood. Glue the circles to the hinge tabs on the lid. Assemble the front and back to the bottom piece. Attach a side then place the lid in the hole on that side. Carefully attach the other side aligning the lid to the hole.
